title: InkLink
subtitle: Breaking writer's block through collaboration
summary: A chain-writing platform that reduces writer's block by turning writing into a shared, low-pressure activity where users contribute one passage at a time.

overview.title: Overview
overview.description:
Everyone has a story they never finished. Maybe it's a novel that stalled at chapter three. Maybe it's a screenplay that never made it past the outline. The ideas were there—the momentum wasn't.

InkLink started with a simple question: what if writing didn't have to be a solo activity? What if the pressure of finishing was replaced by the fun of contributing?

problem.title: The Problem
problem.description:
Writer's block isn't usually about running out of ideas. It's about pressure. The blank page. The expectation of perfection. The lonely weight of being solely responsible for what comes next.

Existing tools like Google Docs and Notion support collaboration, but they're built for productivity—not creative play. Writers need something that removes friction, not something that adds a toolbar.

We wanted to design an experience that removed those barriers—not by making writing easier, but by making it shared.
keyInsights: 72% of surveyed hobbyist writers reported experiencing writer's block at least once a month
Most collaborative tools are designed for productivity, not creative expression
Writers often abandon projects due to isolation, not lack of skill

research.title: Research & Discovery
research.description: We conducted peer surveys with amateur and hobbyist writers, usability testing on early concepts, and concept validation sessions to gauge interest in chain-based collaborative writing.

methods.name: Peer Surveys
methods.description: Distributed Google Forms surveys to 30+ hobbyist writers across writing communities and university groups to understand writing habits, frustrations, and tool usage.

methods.name: Competitive Analysis
methods.description: Evaluated existing platforms including Wattpad, Google Docs, Notion, and collaborative fiction sites to identify gaps in the creative writing collaboration space.

methods.name: Concept Validation
methods.description: Presented the chain-writing concept to potential users through one-on-one interviews and gathered reactions, concerns, and feature wishlists.

keyFindings.detail: Most creative writing happens on desktop or tablet—not mobile phones. Writers wanted screen real estate to see the story unfold.
Text-heavy, cramped layouts made users less likely to read previous contributions and more likely to drop off.
New concepts require gentle onboarding. Users won't explore a novel format like chain-writing without guidance.
Users were significantly more interested when told they'd write a short passage, not a full chapter.

personas.title: User Personas
personas.description: From our research, two primary personas emerged representing the core users InkLink would serve.

userFlows.title: User Flows
userFlows.description: We mapped out the core user journeys to ensure the experience from landing to contributing felt intuitive and low-friction. Three primary flows guided our design decisions.

flows.name: Join & Contribute to a Public Chain
flows.description: The lowest-friction path. New users can read, get inspired, and contribute within minutes of landing on the platform.

flows.name: Start a New Story Chain
flows.description: For users who want to set the tone. Creators define the genre, word limits, and whether the chain is public or private.

flows.name: Private Writing Circle
flows.description: For friend groups or writing clubs. Turn order is set by the creator, offering more structure and familiarity.

informationArchitecture.title: Information Architecture
informationArchitecture.description: We structured InkLink's navigation around three core activities: discovering stories, contributing to chains, and managing your writing. The IA went through two revisions based on card sorting exercises with test participants.

lofi.title: Lo‑Fi Exploration
lofi.description:
Our lo-fi work focused on one core interaction: contributing to a story. We sketched different approaches to showing story history, handling turn-taking, and branching narratives. The visuals were intentionally basic—we needed to test logic, not aesthetics.

What emerged was a simple chain: read what came before, add your piece, pass it on.

explorations.name: Story Reading View
explorations.description: Explored scrolling vs. paginated layouts for reading existing chain contributions. Tested vertical thread, horizontal carousel, and card-stack approaches.
explorations.outcome: Vertical scrolling thread won—users found it the most natural for reading sequential content.

explorations.name: Contribution Interface
explorations.description: Tested inline editing (writing directly below the last passage), modal-based writing (a focused overlay), and split-screen (read left, write right).
explorations.outcome: Split-screen tested best on tablet. Modal worked well on smaller screens as a fallback.

explorations.name: Story Discovery / Browse
explorations.description: Iterated on card-based browsing, list views, and genre-filtered feeds. Explored how much story preview to show before a user commits to reading.
explorations.outcome: Cards with genre tag, contributor count, and a 2-line excerpt struck the right balance of information density.

explorations.name: Turn-Taking System
explorations.description: Sketched queue-based turns, claim-based turns, and free-for-all contribution models. Wireframed status indicators for whose turn it is.
explorations.outcome: Claim-based turns (click to claim, then you have a time window) reduced confusion and felt fair to users.

styleGuide.title: Style Guide & Design System
styleGuide.description: InkLink's visual identity balances warmth and clarity. We wanted the interface to feel inviting—like opening a favorite notebook—while staying clean enough that the writing itself takes center stage. Color is used sparingly, mostly to indicate interactive elements and turn status.

principles.name: Words First
principles.description: Typography and whitespace lead the design. The writing is the content—everything else supports it.

principles.name: Low Visual Noise
principles.description: Minimal chrome, no heavy borders, no competing visual elements. Contributions should flow naturally.

principles.name: Gentle Guidance
principles.description: Progressive disclosure and subtle cues guide users without overwhelming them. The interface teaches through interaction.

body.usage: Body text, story content, descriptions, and UI labels

primary.name: Ink Black
primary.usage: Primary text, headers, key UI elements

accent.name: Story Blue
accent.usage: CTAs, active states, links, turn indicators

spacing.notes: All spacing follows an 8px base grid. Component internal padding uses 12–16px. Section spacing uses 48–64px.

components.name: Story Card
components.description: Displays story preview with genre tag, excerpt, contributor count, and progress indicator. Rounded corners (12px), subtle shadow on hover.

components.name: Contribution Editor
components.description: Minimal writing interface with word count, character limit bar, and submit action. Auto-saves drafts. Distraction-free by default.

components.name: Turn Indicator
components.description: Shows current turn holder with avatar, timer countdown, and claim button for open turns.

components.name: Chain Thread
components.description: Vertically stacked passages with contributor attribution, timestamps, and smooth scroll-to-latest behavior.

components.name: Navigation Bar
components.description: Persistent top nav with logo, search, notifications bell, and profile avatar. Collapses to hamburger on mobile.

components.name: Genre Tag
components.description: Pill-shaped labels for categorizing stories. Color-coded by genre family.

challenges.title: Early Challenges & Pivots
challenges.description: We made three major pivots based on user feedback and testing. Each one felt like a step backward at the time, but ended up pushing the design forward.

pivots.reason: Writers consistently preferred larger screens. Mobile felt cramped for both reading and contributing. Survey data showed 78% of creative writing sessions happened on tablet or desktop.
The newspaper aesthetic looked interesting but hurt readability. Hierarchy got lost in the visual noise. Users spent more time parsing the layout than engaging with stories.

pivots.from: Feature-heavy homepage with multiple entry points
pivots.reason: Users were overwhelmed by options. Heatmap data from Maze testing showed scattered attention. One clear path reduced hesitation and increased story engagement by 40%.

removedFeatures: Branching narratives (too complex for MVP—users wanted linear chains)
Real-time co-editing (shifted to turn-based to preserve individual voice)
Gamification badges (felt inauthentic to creative writing culture)
AI writing suggestions (users wanted human collaboration, not AI assistance)
Comment threads on individual passages (simplified to reactions only)
challenges.reflection: Every feature we removed made the core experience stronger. We learned that for a creative tool, less truly is more—constraint breeds creativity.

iterations.title: Mid-Fidelity Iterations
iterations.description: Between wireframes and final designs, we ran two rounds of mid-fidelity testing to validate layout decisions and interaction patterns. These iterations caught several usability issues before we invested in visual polish.

rounds.focus: Story reading flow & contribution entry point
findings: Users missed the 'Contribute' button when it was placed at the bottom of long story threads
Reading progress indicator helped users orient within longer chains
Contributors wanted to see who wrote each passage before committing to continue
changes: Moved contribution CTA to a sticky floating position
Added a vertical progress bar for chain reading
Added contributor avatars and mini-bios beside each passage

findings: Genre filters were underused—users preferred browsing 'trending' and 'new' feeds
First-time users needed a sample story to understand the chain concept
Story card previews with 2-line excerpts outperformed title-only cards
changes: Replaced genre grid with trending/new/following tabs as primary navigation
Added an interactive onboarding story that walks new users through reading and contributing
Enriched story cards with excerpt, contributor count, and time-remaining badge

hifi.title: High-Fidelity Mockups
hifi.description: The high-fidelity designs leaned into typography and whitespace. We wanted the words to breathe. Color was used sparingly—mostly to indicate interactive elements and turn status. The writing itself stayed neutral, letting each contributor's voice come through without visual interference.

screens.name: Home / Story Feed
screens.description: A clean feed of active story chains with trending, new, and following tabs. Each card shows genre, excerpt, contributor count, and time remaining. The single primary CTA—'Start a Chain'—anchors the top of the page.

screens.name: Story Reading View
screens.description: The heart of the app. Passages stack vertically with contributor attribution. A floating 'Continue This Story' button stays accessible as you scroll. Progress bar on the left tracks your position.

screens.name: Contribution Editor
screens.description: A focused, distraction-free writing space. Word count and character limit are subtly displayed. The previous passage is visible above for context. Auto-save indicator gives writers confidence.

screens.name: Story Creation
screens.description: Simple form for starting a new chain. Set title, genre, contribution rules, and privacy. The opening passage editor sits below the settings, encouraging creators to write immediately.

screens.name: Writing Circle Dashboard
screens.description: Private group management view. Shows active stories, member list with turn order, and circle activity. Clean layout with member avatars and status indicators.

screens.name: Profile & My Stories
screens.description: Personal hub showing your contributions, stories you've started, and stories you're following. Stats include total words contributed, chains participated in, and reading streak.

screens.name: Full-Screen Reading Mode
screens.description: A distraction-free reading experience with generous margins, comfortable line length, and soft background. Toggle between light and sepia themes. All chrome fades away.

screens.name: Onboarding Walkthrough
screens.description: Three-step interactive onboarding that teaches the chain-writing concept. Users read a sample story, contribute a practice passage, and submit it—experiencing the full loop before browsing real chains.

improvements: Highlighted CTAs for joining stories with motion and scale
Removed containers; visuals float in whitespace for editorial impact
Retuned animations for snappy ease-in/ease-out interactions
Progressive reveal interactions to guide users
Focused on typography and generous whitespace
Added micro-interactions for submission confirmation and turn transitions

prototype.title: Interactive Prototype
prototype.description: We built a fully interactive Figma prototype covering the three core flows: browsing and joining a public chain, starting a new story, and managing a private writing circle. The prototype was used for all usability testing sessions.
flows: Browse → Read story → Claim turn → Write → Submit
Create new chain → Set rules → Write opening → Publish
Create writing circle → Invite friends → Manage turns

userTesting.title: Usability Testing
userTesting.description: We conducted two rounds of moderated usability testing—once on mid-fidelity wireframes and once on the final high-fidelity prototype. Sessions were conducted remotely via Zoom with screen sharing, and task completion was tracked through Maze.

tasks: Find and read an active story chain
Contribute a passage to an existing story
Start a new story chain and set it to public

findings.finding: 3 of 5 users couldn't locate the contribute button on first attempt
findings.change: Moved CTA to a persistent floating position with higher visual contrast

findings.finding: Users didn't understand the turn system without explanation
findings.change: Added inline tooltips and an onboarding story that demonstrates the turn-taking flow

findings.finding: Genre filter placement felt buried in the sidebar
findings.change: Replaced sidebar genre filter with horizontal tab navigation (Trending / New / Following)

tasks: Browse stories and join an active chain
Create a private writing circle and invite a friend

findings.finding: Timer countdown created mild anxiety for 2 participants
findings.change: Made timed contributions optional with a clear toggle, and added 'no pressure' copy

findings.finding: Users wanted confirmation that their contribution was saved before submitting
findings.change: Added auto-save indicator and a 'saved as draft' toast notification

findings.finding: One participant expected to see a word count goal, not just a limit
findings.change: Added an optional suggested word range (e.g., '150–300 words') alongside the hard limit

finalPresentation.title: Final Presentation
finalPresentation.description: Our final presentation walks through the complete design journey—from initial research findings through pivots, iterations, and the final solution. Presented as a Figma slide deck.

solution.title: Final Solution
solution.description: InkLink is a collaborative writing platform with three core modes of engagement. The design prioritizes low-friction entry, creative momentum, and the joy of building something together.

features.title: Public Story Chains
features.description: Open stories that anyone can contribute to. Writers join, add a passage, and pass the story forward. Low barrier to entry—no commitment required. Browse by trending, new, or genre.

features.title: Private Writing Circles
features.description: Invite-only spaces for friends or writing groups. Turn order is set by the creator. Offers control and familiarity. Perfect for writing clubs, classrooms, or friend groups.

features.title: Timed Contributions
features.description: Optional time limits encourage momentum. If a turn expires, the next writer can step in. Deadlines reduce overthinking—users can toggle this on or off per story.

features.title: Full-Screen Reading Mode
features.description: A distraction-free space to read completed and in-progress chains. Generous whitespace, comfortable typography, and light/sepia theme options. Made for immersion.

features.title: Built-In Word Processor
features.description: A clean, minimal editor that lives inside the app. Markdown support, word count tracking, and auto-save. No need to leave InkLink to write.

features.title: Guided Onboarding
features.description: New users experience the full chain-writing loop through an interactive sample story before they encounter real content. Teaches by doing, not by explaining.

validation.title: Validation & Results
validation.description: Across both testing rounds, the feedback consistently highlighted that InkLink made writing feel approachable and fun. The reduced pressure was noticeable—users said they felt less precious about their contributions because they knew someone else would build on them.

insights.title: Creativity benefits from constraints
insights.description: Limiting options (one clear CTA, timed turns, word limits) reduced friction instead of adding it. Writers felt freed, not restricted.

insights.title: Visual clarity beats thematic styling
insights.description: The newspaper aesthetic was fun but counterproductive. Clean, minimal design let the content—the writing itself—be the hero.

insights.title: Reducing features can increase engagement
insights.description: We cut more than we added—and the product got better. Every removed feature simplified the mental model for users.

insights.title: Test assumptions early and cheaply
insights.description: Our mobile-first assumption would have cost weeks if we hadn't tested it with lo-fi wireframes first. Low-cost validation saved us from expensive pivots.

insights.title: Onboarding is part of the product, not separate from it
insights.description: The interactive sample story wasn't just a tutorial—it was the most effective way to communicate InkLink's value proposition.

nextSteps.title: Next Steps
items: Add saved drafts so writers can step away mid-contribution without losing progress
Improve accessibility with keyboard navigation, screen reader support, and WCAG AA compliance
Design better onboarding for first-time users unfamiliar with chain writing
Explore branching narratives as a future feature—where chains can fork into alternate storylines
Build a notification system that gently nudges contributors when their turn is approaching
Conduct longitudinal testing to understand long-term engagement and retention patterns
